title: The Exodus Miracles
shortSummary: Psalm 114 poetically recounts the miraculous events of Israel's deliverance from Egypt, highlighting God's sovereign power over nature. It celebrates how the Red Sea and Jordan River obeyed God's command, demonstrating His authority and faithfulness to His covenant people.

keyCharacters.name: Israel
keyCharacters.description: The nation delivered from Egyptian bondage, representing God's chosen people.

keyCharacters.name: Jacob
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch whose descendants became the tribes of Israel; his 'house' is referenced as God's possession.

keyCharacters.name: Judah
keyCharacters.description: One of the tribes of Israel, described as God's sanctuary and dominion, symbolizing God's protective presence.

definitions.definition: A sacred place or refuge; here, it signifies Judah as a holy and protected portion of Israel.
Authority or sovereign rule; indicating Israel as God's possession under His control.
A hard type of rock; used metaphorically to show God's power to bring forth water from the driest places.
To shake or quake in fear or awe; expressing the earth's reaction to God's presence.

outline.heading: Israel's Deliverance from Egypt
outline.description: The psalm opens by recalling Israel's exodus from Egypt, emphasizing their identity as God's chosen people and His sanctuary and dominion.

outline.heading: Nature's Response to God's Power
outline.description: The psalmist describes how the sea fled, the Jordan was driven back, and the mountains and hills moved, illustrating God's control over creation in Israel's deliverance.

outline.heading: Rhetorical Questions Highlighting Miracles
outline.description: Questions are posed to the sea, Jordan, mountains, and hills, emphasizing the extraordinary nature of their actions at God's command.

outline.heading: The Earth Trembles at God's Presence
outline.description: The psalm concludes by calling the earth to tremble before the Lord, who transformed rock into water, symbolizing His life-giving power and presence.

application: Trust in God's sovereign power over all circumstances, knowing He can make a way where there seems to be none.
Remember God's faithfulness in past deliverances as encouragement to remain obedient and faithful in trials.
Approach God with reverence and awe, recognizing His authority over creation and our lives.
Celebrate and proclaim God's mighty works as a testimony to His saving power.

keyVerses.text: The sea saw it, and fled: Jordan was driven back.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's miraculous control over nature to protect and deliver His people.

keyVerses.text: Tremble, thou earth, at the presence of the Lord, at the presence of the God of Jacob;
keyVerses.significance: It calls for reverence and awe before God's powerful presence.

keyVerses.text: Which turned the rock into a standing water, the flint into a fountain of waters.
keyVerses.significance: This verse illustrates God's ability to bring life and provision from the most unlikely sources.
